summary.seg: A sixteenth-century copy of the Vision of Piers Plowman, one of the most famous medieval texts in English, by the otherwise largely unknown figure, William Langland. Written in the late fourteenth century, this allegorical dream vision poem offers both a quest of personal purification, and a critique of lax morals at all levels of Langland's society. It details the encounters of a pilgrim, Will, with various allegorical figures representing the soul's journey to salvation and the perils along the way; this varied and colourful cast of characters includes the mysterious Piers the plowman, who has a strong connection to Christ.

The poem survives in more than 50 manuscripts in three distinct versions, labelled A, B and C. CUL MS Gg.4.31 is a copy of the most widely accepted and edited version, the B text. Its significance primarily lies in the evidence it offers of continued interest in and engagement with the text in the sixteenth century, possibly due to its critique of the immorality of lax clergy. Gg.4.31 is unique in containing a table of contents after the main text, on folio 101v onwards, which may represent an otherwise unattested personal engagement with the Piers Plowman text on the part of the original scribe, or annotator who signs him/herself W. H. There is also a short devotional poem at the end of the manuscript.

msItem.title: The Vision of Piers Plowman
msItem.author: Langland, William, 1330?-1400?
msItem.rubric: 1r Hic Incipit Petrus plow[man] de visione liber primus
msItem.incipit: 1r In a someres seyson, when soft was the sonne, I shoope me in srowdes as I a shepe were, In habyte as a heremyte vnholy off werkes, wente wyde yn thys world wonders to here
msItem.explicit: 101r & send me happe & heale tyll I have pyers þe plowman & sythe he gradde after grace tyll I gan awake

msItem.title: Table of contents for Piers Plowman
msItem.rubric: 101v Here ynsuethe þe table off pyers plowman
msItem.incipit: 101v þe first passe off þe vysyone conteynethe iii chapters

msItem.title: A goodly prayer
msItem.incipit: 104r Blessed god sovereange goodnes mercy to me þi synfull creature
msItem.explicit: 105v where we may behold thy bryght vysage with angelles & seyntes syngyng in kynd sanctus sanctus sanctus lord god withowte end

support.material: Paper. According to Jefferson (2011), the paper of the main text has a watermark of a waterwheel with teeth + three oak leaves, cf. Briquet 13396 (1514), Heawood 4025 (1579), Heawood 4024 (undated). The last is the closest to the watermark in Gg.4.31 and, according to Michael Beazeley, can be dated to 1544.

supportDesc.foliation: Original foliation in ink, originally in the upper right corner of each recto, but has been cropped from several pages. Modern pencial foliation, can be seen in the same location on some pages, sometimes replacing the older foliation, or alongside it.

collation.p:
The MS consists of 9 quires as follows:
2 modern paper flyleaves
Quire 112 (fols 1-11; folio 1 has been cut out)
Quires 28 (fols 2-19)
Quire 316 (fols 20-35)
Quires 4-812 (fols 36-95)
Quire 912 (fols 96-106; the final folio is missing)
2 modern paper flyleaves

supportDesc.condition: Quite severely cropped in places, with text lost on folio 1r, for example, or on folio 25v. Red staining, from the rubric ink, on folio 17v. Otherwise, generally very good condition.

layout.p: Very varied, particularly between the different texts but generally:

handNote.p: All the texts are written in sixteenth-century Secretary hand by the same scribe. The rubricated sections are written by the same hand but in a different, more careful script.

decoDesc.decoNote: Latin material in the text or rubrics is written in red in Piers Plowman.

additions.p: Running annotations and marginalia add corrections and commentary, many in the hand of the main scribe, but also in two other hands. The second, probably contemporary, hand signs himself WH, see folio 69v or 72v. It is supposed that WH added these notes at the time the manuscript was being rubricated and bound, suggesting he may have been a previous owner.
The final hand, in a sixteenth-century italic, comments on passages dealing with immorality by clerics, see folio 42v or 72v.

bindingDesc.p: Late seventeenth-century binding of blind-tooled leather. The manuscript was rebacked by Douglas Cockerell and Son of Letchworth in July 1962, as noted on the first flyleaf. The title The Prophecies of Piers Plowman and shelfmark from the previous binding have been pasted inside the back cover.

history.provenance: Possibly owned and annotated at the time of its creation by someone who signs themselves W.H. In 1656, the manuscript was given by Robert Morgan (1608-1673) Morgan, Robert, 1608-1673 , later bishop of Bangor and alumnus of Jesus College, to Cambridge University Library.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the edition and study of the text prepared by Judith Jefferson in 2011 for the Piers Plowman Electronic Archive.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions). Contact the Manuscripts Department for further information on the availability of this manuscript
